Cantor set, Painlevé's theorem

Let E⊆[0,1]E \subseteq \br{0, 1}E⊆[0,1] denote the Cantor 'middle thirds' set; namely, the set E={∑i≥1bi3−i∣bi=0,2}E = \set{\sum_{i\geq1} b_i3^{-i} \mid b_i = 0, 2}E={∑i≥1​bi​3−i∣bi​=0,2}. Embedding [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1] naturally into C\CC, we regard EEE as a subset of C\CC. Suppose f ⁣:C∖E→C\func{f}{\C \setminus E}{\C}f:C∖E→C is holomorphic and (uniformly) bounded. Show that fff is constant.
Solution.

Notice that EEE has Lebesgue measure zero, i.e.,

m(E)=inf⁡ {∑n=1∞∣bn−an∣ | E⊆⋃n=1∞(an,bn)},m\p{E} = \inf\,\set{\sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{b_n - a_n} \st E \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty \p{a_n, b_n}},m(E)=inf{n=1∑∞​∣bn​−an​∣∣∣​E⊆n=1⋃∞​(an​,bn​)},

by outer regularity of the Lebesgue measure.

Let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. Then there exists a family {B(xn,rn)}n\set{B\p{x_n, r_n}}_n{B(xn​,rn​)}n​ of balls in C\CC such that E⊆⋃n=1∞B(xn,rn)E \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty B\p{x_n, r_n}E⊆⋃n=1∞​B(xn​,rn​) and ∑n=1∞rn<ε\sum_{n=1}^\infty r_n < \epsilon∑n=1∞​rn​<ε. By removing balls which are disjoint from EEE, we see that such a family is contained in the ball B(0,1+ε)B\p{0, 1 + \epsilon}B(0,1+ε). By compactness, there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that E⊆⋃n=1NB(xn,rn)E \subseteq \bigcup_{n=1}^N B\p{x_n, r_n}E⊆⋃n=1N​B(xn​,rn​). Let

γε=∂(⋃n=1NB(xn,rn))\gamma_\epsilon = \partial\p{\bigcup_{n=1}^N B\p{x_n, r_n}}γε​=∂(n=1⋃N​B(xn​,rn​))

and orient it counter-clockwise. Let B=B(0,2)B = B\p{0, 2}B=B(0,2) so that γε⊆B\gamma_\epsilon \subseteq Bγε​⊆B for all ε∈(0,1)\epsilon \in \p{0, 1}ε∈(0,1), which gives us the following annular decomposition of fff on B∖⋃n=1NB(xn,rn)B \setminus \bigcup_{n=1}^N B\p{x_n, r_n}B∖⋃n=1N​B(xn​,rn​):

f(z)=12πi∫∂Bf(ζ)ζ−z dζ−12πi∫γεf(ζ)ζ−z dζ.f\p{z} = \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial B} \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zeta - \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\gamma_\epsilon} \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zeta.f(z)=2πi1​∫∂B​ζ−zf(ζ)​dζ−2πi1​∫γε​​ζ−zf(ζ)​dζ.

Thus, if z∈B∖Ez \in B \setminus Ez∈B∖E, then d(z,E)>0d\p{z, E} > 0d(z,E)>0. If we shrink ε\epsilonε to, say, smaller than a quarter of this distance, then d(z,γε)≥d(z,E)2≕δ>0d\p{z, \gamma_\epsilon} \geq \frac{d\p{z, E}}{2} \eqqcolon \delta > 0d(z,γε​)≥2d(z,E)​=:δ>0 since we required that all the balls above intersect EEE. Hence,

∣f(z)−12πi∫∂Bf(ζ)ζ−z dζ∣≤12π∫γε∣f(ζ)ζ−z∣ d∣ζ∣≤12π∥f∥L∞δ∣γε∣≤12π∥f∥L∞δ∑n=1N2πrn=∥f∥L∞δε→ε→00.\begin{aligned} \abs{f\p{z} - \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial B} \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zeta} &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{\gamma_\epsilon} \abs{\frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z}} \,\diff\abs{\zeta} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \frac{\norm{f}_{L^\infty}}{\delta} \abs{\gamma_\epsilon} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \frac{\norm{f}_{L^\infty}}{\delta} \sum_{n=1}^N 2\pi r_n \\ &= \frac{\norm{f}_{L^\infty}}{\delta}\epsilon \xrightarrow{\epsilon\to0} 0. \end{aligned}∣∣​f(z)−2πi1​∫∂B​ζ−zf(ζ)​dζ∣∣​​≤2π1​∫γε​​∣∣​ζ−zf(ζ)​∣∣​d∣ζ∣≤2π1​δ∥f∥L∞​​∣γε​∣≤2π1​δ∥f∥L∞​​n=1∑N​2πrn​=δ∥f∥L∞​​εε→0​0.​

In other words, if g(z)=12πi∫∂Bf(ζ)ζ−z dζg\p{z} = \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial B} \frac{f\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zetag(z)=2πi1​∫∂B​ζ−zf(ζ)​dζ, then ggg is holomorphic on B(0,2)B\p{0, 2}B(0,2) and fff agrees with ggg on B(0,2)∖EB\p{0, 2} \setminus EB(0,2)∖E. Hence, fff extends to an entire function, which completes the proof.
